awd_titl_txt: Wisconsin Materials Research Science and Engineering Center
awd_abstract_narration:
NonTechnical Abstract: The Wisconsin MRSEC brings together teams of researchers - undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty - from diverse disciplinary backgrounds from across the University of Wisconsin-Madison and other key partner universities to understand at the level of atoms and molecules how to create new materials that will enable next-generation technologies.  By addressing fundamental challenges related to a critical void in knowledge involving disorder in materials, and the emergence of order from disordered materials, new materials for telecommunications, clean energy, quantum information sciences and biotechnologies are being developed.  The Center integrates the discovery and sharing of new knowledge with national leadership in development and dissemination of research-inspired educational materials for K-12 and the public, innovative projects that broaden participation of groups underrepresented in STEM fields, development of new characterization facilities that integrate data analysis and sharing, industry outreach to promote regional economic development, and professional development and international opportunities that train the next-generation US workforce.

Technical Abstract: Center research is organized into two interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs) each addressing complex challenges involving metals, inorganic oxides, semiconductors and organic molecular assemblies. The IRGs unite 44 senior investigators from 9 disciplines, and integrate synthesis, structural characterization, theory/simulation, property evaluation and applications. IRG1, entitled Stability in Glasses: New Materials and New Insights, leverages the cross fertilization of ideas and techniques from inorganic and organic glass research to address fundamental questions related to processes, structure and properties of glasses, building on the discovery that physical vapor deposition can increase kinetic and thermodynamic stability of organic glass films. IRG1 is enabling diverse applications by creating ultrastable glass thin films of various materials, including ultralow-loss oxide dielectrics for quantum computing and mirrors, ultra-smooth metallic glass hard coatings, and materials for organic electronics.  IRG2, entitled Order from Disorder: Approaches for New Thin-Film Oxides, understands and engineers the growth of structurally, chemically and topographically complex epitaxial metal oxide crystals from amorphous layers, with a focus on compositions of oxides unconstrained by requirements of thermodynamic stability, and 3D geometries that are inaccessible via current methods.  IRG2 controls atomic reordering and solid-state mass transport during crystallization to impact technologies from electronics, ionic transport, and optics to areas as diverse as glass devitrification in nuclear storage and biomineralization.  Both IRGs provide an interdisciplinary and multi-institutional learning environment for graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduates, in which the research focuses on the important area of glass science and the development of multi-functional and earth-friendly materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Wisconsin Materials Research Science and Engineering Center pursued ground-breaking research in the emergence of order from disordered materials, developed new instrumentation for materials research, promoted broad participation in research at all academic levels, and shared the excitement of cutting-edge research with the general public through research-inspired content.

One of the Center’s research thrusts was the development and understanding of new, more stable glass materials. Glasses are ubiquitous in everyday life, from windows to plastic bottles, but they also underlie technologies such as organic LED displays for cell phones and TVs. The Center discovered and understood new ways to make glasses using the unusually fast motion of atoms on glass surfaces. The resulting materials range from ultrahard coatings to materials that emit and absorb light in unusual ways.

The Center’s other research thrust was the development and understanding of new ways to make highly ordered crystalline thin films from solid but disordered starting materials. Usually, crystal films are made by condensing a vapor. Starting from a disordered solid instead let the Center create otherwise inaccessible materials that may be a key part of next-generation solid state lighting devices and transparent electronics, or which can patterned into tiny, nanometer-scale islands for quantum technologies.

To support these efforts, the Center developed the world’s fastest electron microscopy camera and a system to focus synchrotron x-rays onto a thin film as it grows. Both instruments allowed Center researchers and other scientists to watch how atoms move and rearrange in real time, offering unprecedented views into how materials grow and change.

Researchers and education professionals in the Center developed educational content for K-12 students based on the Center’s research. One example is the educational video game “Crystal Cave”, available through the BrainPop website, that guides elementary school students through exploring how atoms fit together in ordered arrays to form crystals. The Center engaged tens of thousands of K-12 students and public audiences in person through the Wisconsin Science Festival, Engineering Expo, and programs for K-12 teachers and millions more people online through games, YouTube, and the Center education website. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Center created and distributed free, inclusive science activity kits to thousands of people in Wisconsin, many of whom are economically disadvantaged.


Last Modified: 10/03/2024
Modified by: Paul M Voyles

Images (1 of )
  • Members of the Wisconsin MRSEC (gray t-shirts) sharing the excitement of materials research with the general public through hands-on demonstrations at the Wisconsin Science Festival
    AnneLynn Gillian-Daniel
    Creative Commons
    Paul M Voyles
    Outreach at the Wisconsin Science Festival
  • Orientation of molecules in a glassy thin film measured by MRSEC researchers. The size and arrangement of the orientation domains effects the performance of this organic semiconductor for applications like organic light emitting diodes.
    Debaditya Chatterjee and Paul Voyles
    Creative Commons
    Paul M Voyles
    Molecular orientation domains in a glassy thin film
  • Snapshots from an atomistic simulation of how disordered material (blue / gray) transformed into ordered, crystalline material (orange/red) starting from a nanoscale seed (pink / blue).
    Tesia Janicki and J. R. Schmidt
    Copyrighted
    Paul M Voyles
    Simulation of crystallization from a nanoscale seed
